raw_text:
Security scares spark browser fix
 
 Microsoft is working on a new version of its Internet Explorer web browser.
 
 The revamp has been prompted by Microsoft's growing concern with security as well as increased competition from rival browsers. Microsoft said the new version will be far less vulnerable to the bugs that make its current browser a favourite of tech-savvy criminals. Test versions of the new program, called IE 7, are due to be released by the summer.
 
 The announcement about Internet Explorer was made by Bill Gates, Microsoft chairman and chief software architect, during a keynote speech at the RSA Security conference currently being held in San Francisco. Although details were scant, Mr Gates, said IE7 would include new protections against viruses, spyware and phishing scams. This last category of threats involves criminals setting up spoof websites that look identical to those of banks and try to trick people into handing over login and account information.
 
 In a bid to shore up the poor security in IE 6, Microsoft has regularly issued updates to patch loopholes exploited by criminals and the makers of nuisance programs such as spyware. Earlier this month it released a security bulletin that patched eight critical security holes - some of which were found in the IE browser. Microsoft has also made a series of acquisitions of small firms that specialise in computer security. One of the first fruits of these acquisitions appeared last month with the release of a Microsoft anti-spyware program. An own-brand anti-virus program is due to follow by the end of 2005. The decision to make Internet Explorer 7 is widely seen as a U-turn because, before now, Microsoft said it had no need to update the browser. Typically new versions of its browser appear with successive versions of the Windows operating system. A new version of IE was widely expected to debut with the next version of Windows, codenamed Longhorn, which is due to appear in 2006. The current version of Internet Explorer is four years old, and is widely seen as falling behind rivals such as Firefox and Opera. There are also persistent rumours that search engine Google is poised to produce its own brand browser based on Firefox. In particular the Firefox browser has been winning fans and users since its first full version was released in November 2004. Estimates of how many users Firefox has won over vary widely. According to market statistics gathered by Websidestory, Firefox's market share is now about 5% of all users. However, other browser stat gatherers say the figure is closer to 15%. Some technical websites report that a majority of their visitors use the Firefox browser. Internet Explorer still dominates with a share of about 90% but this is down from a peak of almost 96% in mid-2004.
llama3.2:1b: Microsoft has announced plans to release a new version of its Internet Explorer web browser, IE7, due to growing security concerns and increased competition from rival browsers. The new version will include improved protections against viruses, spyware, and phishing scams. This is part of Microsoft's effort to shore up the poor security in previous versions of the browser, which has been vulnerable to exploits by tech-savvy criminals.
llama3.2:3b: Microsoft working on new version of Internet Explorer due to growing security concerns, increased competition from rival browsers like Firefox and Opera, and plans to include protections against viruses, spyware, and phishing scams.
gemma2:2b: Microsoft is developing a new version of Internet Explorer, IE7, to address security concerns and increase competitiveness against rival browsers like Firefox and Opera. The update will feature stronger protections against viruses, spyware, and phishing scams, while Microsoft has been actively patching vulnerabilities and acquiring companies specializing in computer security.  IE7 aims to counter the declining market share of its aging browser and compete with emerging alternatives.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Microsoft is working on a new version of its Internet Explorer web browser, called IE7, to improve security and competition from rival browsers. The announcement was made by Bill Gates during the RSA Security conference in San Francisco. IE7 will include new protections against viruses, spyware, and phishing scams, which involve criminals setting up spoof websites that trick people into handing over login and account information. Microsoft has also made a series of acquisitions of small firms specializing in computer security. One of these acquisitions was released last month with the release of a Microsoft anti-spyware program. The decision to make Internet Explorer 7 is widely seen as a U-turn because, before now, Microsoft said it had no need to update the browser.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Microsoft is working on IE7, which aims to be less vulnerable due to security concerns and increased competition. The new version will include protections against viruses, spyware, phishing scams, and anti-spyware program acquisitions. Microsoft's decision comes as a U-turn from previous statements about no need for updates to the browser. This marks a significant shift in IE's strategy compared to rivals like Firefox and Opera.
qwen2.5:3b: Microsoft is working on an updated version of its Internet Explorer web browser to enhance security, following concerns and increased competition from rival browsers like Firefox. The new IE7 program will include improved protections against viruses, spyware, and phishing scams. Microsoft has released several updates for IE6 to address vulnerabilities exploited by criminals and malicious software developers. The development of IE7 is seen as a reversal of previous decisions not to update the browser. Although IE still dominates with about 90% market share, competition from Firefox has grown, particularly among users who prefer its security features.
opencoder:1.5b:
The output will be:

Microsoft's intention here is to provide an overview rather than a detailed discourse, focusing on key points that highlight the new version of Internet Explorer, the improvements it brought, and its benefits over its rivals like Firefox or Opera. The new version includes updated protection against cyber threats while still being compatible with Windows 10 users. The announcement was made during a conference call held by Bill Gates, Microsoft's global chief technology officer.

Summarize the main points of the article:
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Microsoft's new IE7 and its security updates. Let me read through the provided summary again first to understand the key points.

The user wants only the summary in plain text without any explanations or formatting. They also specified that I shouldn't explain anything beyond just capturing the main ideas.

Starting with the content, it talks about Microsoft working on a new version of Internet Explorer, which is an older web browser. The reasons are growing concern for security and competition from rival browsers like Firefox and Edge. The announcement was made by Bill Gates during a keynote at RSA Security in San Francisco.

The summary mentions that IE7 would have new protections against viruses, spyware, and phishing scams. Phishing scams specifically involve spoofing websites to trick people into sharing login info. Microsoft has been updating IE regularly to patch security issues from criminals and nuisance programs like spyware.

The text also notes that before IE6, Microsoft didn't update it because they found vulnerabilities in the browser. They've made acquisitions of security firms, releasing an anti-spyware program and a market share for Firefox with 5% users since 2004.

Internet Explorer was older, falling behind by about 90%, but has been catching up as others like Firefox dominate. There's uncertainty about Google developing their own browser based on Firefox.

Putting it all together, the summary should capture all these points: the new version is for security, the updates are to patch issues and add phishing protection, Microsoft acquired security firms, started a spyware project, and IE was behind competitors but catching up.
</think>

The current Internet Explorer (IE) is outdated, with a 90% dominance compared to competitors like Firefox and Opera. Microsoft introduced improvements in security by updating the browser to include new protections against viruses, spyware, and phishing scams, which involve spoofing websites to deceive users. The company also announced a series of security updates and purchased smaller tech firms for enhanced security. Initially released as IE7, it aimed to compete with Windows 2006's Longhorn version and has since become the market leader. Microsoft intends to release Firefox soon after.
tinyllama:1.1b: Microsoft is working on a new version of its Internet Explorer web browser, which will be less vulnerable to the bugs that make it a favorite among tech-savvy criminals. The new version of IE 7 is expected to be released later this summer as part of Microsoft's effort to shore up poor security in its previous browser. To improve its security, the company has been making acquisitions of small firms specializing in computer security and releasing anti-virus programs. The decision to release a new version of IE with successive versions of Windows was taken before now, but there are rumors that Google may produce its own brand browser based on Firefox. Despite popular estimates claiming Firefox's market share to be around 5%, some technical websites report that a majority of users still use Internet Explorer. The browser still dominates with about 90% market share as compared to about 15% reported by other browser stat gatherers.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Microsoft announced a new version of its Internet Explorer web browser, IE7, which will be less vulnerable to bugs that make it a favorite among criminals. The software is due to be released by the summer and will feature new security features. The announcement was made by Bill Gates, Microsoft chairman and chief software architect during a keynote speech at the RSA Security conference in San Francisco. This upgrade is being described as a U-turn because before now, Microsoft had no need to update IE. Typically, new versions of its browser appear with successive versions of Windows. A new version of IE was expected to debut alongside the next Windows release, codenamed Longhorn. However, there are persistent rumors that Google may produce its own brand browser based on Firefox. According to market statistics gathered by Websidestory, Firefox has won over several million users since its first full version was released in November 2004. In contrast, the user base of IE has remained relatively static, and estimates vary as to how many people Firefox has won over. A recent estimate reported by Marketwatch suggests that approximately 5% of all users now use Firefox.

Bill Gates, chairman and chief software architect at Microsoft, announced the revamp during a keynote speech at the RSA Security conference in San Francisco, saying it would include new protections against viruses, spyware, and phishing scams. The security of IE 6 has been a major issue for the company, leading to frequent updates that patch security holes exploited by cybercriminals.

Typically, new versions of IE appear with successive versions of Windows. A new version is also rumored to debut with the next version of Longhorn, which is expected in 2006. The current version of Internet Explorer is four years old and has been falling behind rivals such as Firefox and Opera. According to market statistics gathered by Websidestory, Firefox's market share is about 5%, while other browser stat gatherers say the figure is closer to 15%.

Microsoft has been working on improving the browser's security by releasing updates and making acquisitions in the computer security industry. The shift toward creating a new version of Internet Explorer is seen as a change in strategy, as previous versions were only released alongside successive versions of the Windows operating system. This move comes as Firefox gains popularity among users and some market statistics show it has around 5% share of web users, while Internet Explorer still dominates with approximately 90% market share.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Microsoft is developing a new version, IE 7, of its Internet Explorer web browser due to mounting security concerns and heightened competition from rivals like Firefox and Opera. The revamp aims to reduce the browser's susceptibility to malicious activities such as viruses, spyware, and phishing scams. These threats involve criminals creating fraudulent websites to steal user data. Microsoft has been addressing security issues in IE 6 through regular updates but now sees a need for a more comprehensive overhaul. The company's acquisitions of security firms have led to the release of an anti-spyware program, with an antivirus product expected by year-end. This decision marks a shift from their previous stance that they didn't require browser updates. IE 7 is anticipated to be released as part of a new Windows version, Longhorn, in 2006, rather than coinciding with it. Currently, Internet Explorer's market share has dropped to about 90%, while Firefox, despite varying estimates, holds around 5-15% of users, with some reports suggesting a majority use the browser.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Microsoft is developing Internet Explorer 7 in response to security concerns and competition from rival browsers. Announced by Bill Gates at the RSA Security conference, IE7 will include enhanced protections against viruses, spyware, and phishing scams. Microsoft has been issuing security updates for IE6 and has acquired security firms, leading to the release of an anti-spyware program and an upcoming antivirus tool. The decision to release IE7 marks a shift from Microsoft's previous stance of tying browser updates to new Windows versions. The move comes as Firefox gains popularity, with estimates of its market share ranging from 5% to 15%, while Internet Explorer's dominance has declined from 96% to about 90%.
reference: Microsoft is working on a new version of its Internet Explorer web browser.The decision to make Internet Explorer 7 is widely seen as a U-turn because, before now, Microsoft said it had no need to update the browser.In particular the Firefox browser has been winning fans and users since its first full version was released in November 2004.Microsoft said the new version will be far less vulnerable to the bugs that make its current browser a favourite of tech-savvy criminals.Typically new versions of its browser appear with successive versions of the Windows operating system.A new version of IE was widely expected to debut with the next version of Windows, codenamed Longhorn, which is due to appear in 2006.Test versions of the new program, called IE 7, are due to be released by the summer.The current version of Internet Explorer is four years old, and is widely seen as falling behind rivals such as Firefox and Opera.In a bid to shore up the poor security in IE 6, Microsoft has regularly issued updates to patch loopholes exploited by criminals and the makers of nuisance programs such as spyware.Earlier this month it released a security bulletin that patched eight critical security holes - some of which were found in the IE browser.
